LeetCode 1. Two Sums

If you prefer a visual explanation, please check out my video here, although bare in mind this is the first video Iâ€™ve recorded so the mic settings werenâ€™t great so it might be easier for you to read the solution here.

TLDR

Source code for my O(N) TypeScript solution using a hashmap

The problem

We have two params, an array of numbers and a target.

The goal here is to find which two numbers in the array sum up to the target and output their indexes.

An example here:

let nums = [2, 7, 13, 5, 8, 11, 1, 4];
let target = 10;

// Output [0, 4]
nums[0] + nums[4] === 10 // 2 + 8 = 10

Brute force solution

The easiest way to solve this would be to loop through our nums array and for every number, check if that number + any other number in the array matches our target.

Hereâ€™s a draw up of our algorithm

If it does, return the two indexes that made up our sum.

function twoSum(nums: number[], target: number): number[] {
Â  Â  for (let i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) {
Â  Â  Â  Â  for (let j = 0; j < nums.length; j++) {
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  // Can't use the same idx twice
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  if (i === j) {
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  continue
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  }
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  if (nums[i] + nums[j] === target) {
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  return [i, j];
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  }
Â  Â  Â  Â  }
Â  Â  }
};

Efficiency

This solution runs in O(N^2) as it runs through our input twice.

Hash Table Solution

We can store the result of each sum in a hash table and check if the hash table includes the sum of the current array number in our iteration - the target.

If it is, that means we can reach the target with the number in our hash table and the current number weâ€™re iterating through.

A draw up of the solution

function twoSum(nums: number[], target: number): number[] {
Â  Â  const sumResults = {}; // Our hash table
Â  Â  for (let i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) {
Â  Â  Â  Â  let tempSum = target - nums[i];
Â  Â  Â  Â  if (sumResults.hasOwnProperty(target - tempSum)) {
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  return [sumResults[target - tempSum], i]
Â  Â  Â  Â  }
Â  Â  Â  Â  sumResults[tempSum] = i;
Â  Â  }

};

Efficiency

This solution will run in O(N) time complexity as we only iterate through our numberâ€™s array once. It does also have an O(N) space complexity too as weâ€™re creating a hash table that can in the worst case store our entire input too
